Na Kitajskem omejili igranje videoiger za mladoletne
06 Nov 2019, 18:16 by STA

Kitajska je v torek napovedala omejitve pri igranju videoiger za mladoletne. Za mlajše od 18 let bo tako veljala prepoved igranja spletnih videoiger med 22. uro zvečer in 8. uro zjutraj. Prav tako so za mladoletne omejili igranje videoiger na 90 minut ob delovnikih ter na tri ure ob vikendih ali praznikih, na spletni strani poroča britanski BBC.



Fotografija je simbolična. Foto: Pixabay

PEKING > Mladini so tudi omejili mesečno porabo denarja na njihovih računih za videoigre. Igralci, stari od osem do 16 let, bodo tako lahko na mesec zapravili do 200 kitajskih juanov (25,81 evra), tisti, ki so stari od 16 do 18 let, pa 400 kitajskih juanov.
Najnovejše smernice bodo veljale za vse spletne platforme videoiger, ki delujejo na Kitajskem. S pomočjo organov kazenskega pregona bodo vzpostavili enoten identifikacijski sistem, ki bo nastal na osnovi podatkov, ki ga platforme za videoigre uporabljajo za verifikacijo uporabnikove identitete in starosti ter vladnih podatkov.
Gre za najnovejši ukrep v prizadevanjih Kitajske za zajezitev zasvojenosti z videoigrami pri mladini. Kitajska velja za eno največjih tržišč za videoigre na svetu. Hkrati se na Kitajskem krepijo kritike, da videoigre negativno vplivajo na mlade.
Kitajska vlada je že lani napovedala vzpostavitev regulatorjev za videoigre in za devet mesecev tudi zaustavila odobritev novih videoiger.
Svetovna zdravstvena organizacija je lani prvič med duševne bolezni uvrstila zasvojenost z videoigrami.

China restricts video games for minors
06 Nov 2019, 17:16 by STA

China on Tuesday announced restrictions on playing video games for minors. Under-18s will therefore be banned from playing online video games between 10pm and 8am. They also restricted video games to minors to 90 minutes on weekdays and three hours on weekends or public holidays, according to the BBC website.



Photography is symbolic. Photo credit: Pixabay

BEIJING> Young people have also limited their spending on their video game accounts on a monthly basis. Players between the ages of eight and 16 will be able to spend up to 200 Chinese yuan ($ 25.81) a month, while those between 16 and 18 years old will be able to spend 400 Chinese yuan.
The latest guidelines will apply to all online video game platforms operating in China. With the help of law enforcement, they will establish a unified identification system based on data used by video game platforms to verify user identity and age and government data.
This is the latest measure in China's efforts to curb youth video game addiction. China is considered one of the largest video game markets in the world. At the same time, criticism is mounting in China that video games are having a negative impact on young people.
The Chinese government announced last year the establishment of video game regulators and also halted the approval of new video games for nine months.
The World Health Organization ranked video game addiction for the first time last year among mental illnesses.
